title: Rewrite Fallacy
context: A codebase has accumulated years of technical debt, inconsistent patterns, and legacy decisions. The team is frustrated. Someone proposes the solution that feels obvious: rewrite it from scratch. Clean slate. Modern stack. Do it right this time. Leadership approves. The rewrite begins with optimism and ends — if it ends at all — years later, over budget, with a new system that has its own set of problems and has lost years of battle-tested edge case handling.
hypothesis: Rewriting a legacy system from scratch is faster and cheaper than incrementally improving it.

chain.root: Decide to rewrite legacy system from scratch

children.label: Legacy system encoded thousands of implicit business rules
Edge cases discovered only when users hit them in production
Second system effect — team over-engineers the replacement

effects.label: Two systems must be maintained simultaneously

children.label: Bug fixes must be applied to both old and new systems
Feature development stalls — all capacity goes to rewrite
Competitors ship features while you rewrite plumbing

effects.label: Organizational patience runs out
effects.impact: 50-70% of rewrites are abandoned or scaled back

children.label: Leadership loses confidence in engineering estimates
Team morale collapses when rewrite is cancelled or descoped

effects.label: New system accumulates its own debt within 2 years

children.label: The same organizational pressures that created the original debt still exist
Team proposes another rewrite — the cycle repeats

dontIf: The existing system is still generating revenue and serving users
You cannot articulate exactly which business rules the legacy system encodes
ifYouMust: Use the strangler fig pattern — replace incrementally, not all at once
Define a strict feature freeze on the new system — parity first, improvements later
Set a hard deadline and scope cut ruthlessly if behind
Keep the old system running as fallback for at least 6 months post-migration

alternatives.name: Strangler fig pattern
alternatives.note: Incrementally replace components while keeping the old system running

alternatives.name: Modular extraction
alternatives.note: Extract the worst modules into services, leave the rest

alternatives.name: Invest in tests first
alternatives.note: Add comprehensive tests to legacy code, then refactor safely

sources.title: Joel Spolsky: Things You Should Never Do
sources.note: The canonical essay on why rewrites fail — Netscape's rewrite killed the company

sources.title: Martin Fowler: Strangler Fig Application
sources.note: The incremental alternative to big-bang rewrites

sources.title: Fred Brooks: The Mythical Man-Month (Second System Effect)
sources.note: Teams over-engineer the second system, making it bloated and late

sources.title: Herb Caudill: Lessons from 6 Software Rewrite Stories
sources.note: Analysis of Basecamp, FogBugz, Gmail, Netscape, and others — most rewrites fail or barely succeed

falsifiability: A majority of ground-up rewrites are completed on time and within budget
Rewritten systems show measurably lower technical debt than incrementally improved systems after 3 years
Feature velocity during a rewrite period remains within 20% of pre-rewrite levels

seo.description: Software rewrites take 2-3x longer than estimated, stall feature development by 80%, and 50-70% are abandoned. The strangler fig pattern is almost always better.
keywords: software rewrite fallacy second order effects
